framework.description: Name of the threat framework used to further categorize and classify the tactic and technique of the reported threat. Framework classification can be provided by detecting systems, evaluated at ingest time, or retrospectively tagged to events.

alias.description: The alias(es) of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group alias(es).

id.description: The id of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group id.

name.description: The name of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group name.

reference.description: The reference URL of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group reference URL.

number.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

confidence.description: Identifies the confidence rating assigned by the provider using STIX confidence scales. Expected values:   * Not Specified, None, Low, Medium, High   * 0-10   * Admirality Scale (1-6)   * DNI Scale (5-95)   * WEP Scale (Impossible - Certain)

dataset.description: Identifies the name of specific dataset from the intelligence source.

description.description: Describes the type of action conducted by the threat.

domain.description: Identifies a threat indicator as a domain (irrespective of direction).

address.description: Identifies a threat indicator as an email address (irrespective of direction).

accessed.description: Last time the file was accessed. Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.

attributes.description: Array of file attributes. Attributes names will vary by platform. Here's a non-exhaustive list of values that are expected in this field: archive, compressed, directory, encrypted, execute, hidden, read, readonly, system, write.

exists.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

signing_id.description: The identifier used to sign the process. This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

status.description: Additional information about the certificate status. This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

subject_name.description: Subject name of the code signer

team_id.description: The team identifier used to sign the process. This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

trusted.description: Stores the trust status of the certificate chain. Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

valid.description: Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content. Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

created.description: File creation time. Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.

ctime.description: Last time the file attributes or metadata changed. Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.

device.description: Device that is the source of the file.

directory.description: Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

drive_letter.description: Drive letter where the file is located. This field is only relevant on Windows. The value should be uppercase, and not include the colon.

extension.description: File extension, excluding the leading dot. Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

gid.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

group.description: Primary group name of the file.

inode.description: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

mime_type.description: MIME type should identify the format of the file or stream of bytes using https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml[IANA official types], where possible. When more than one type is applicable, the most specific type should be used.

mode.description: Mode of the file in octal representation.

mtime.description: Last time the file content was modified.

name.description: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

path.description: Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

size.description: File size in bytes. Only relevant when `file.type` is "file".

uid.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

first_seen.description: The date and time when intelligence source first reported sighting this indicator.

name.description: User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about. Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names. Not typically used in automated geolocation.

postal_code.description: Postal code associated with the location. Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

timezone.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

ip.description: Identifies a threat indicator as an IP address (irrespective of direction).

last_seen.description: The date and time when intelligence source last reported sighting this indicator.

tlp.description: Traffic Light Protocol sharing markings. Expected values are:   * White   * Green   * Amber   * Red

atomic.description: Identifies the atomic indicator that matched a local environment endpoint or network event.

field.description: Identifies the field of the atomic indicator that matched a local environment endpoint or network event.

type.description: Identifies the type of the atomic indicator that matched a local environment endpoint or network event.

module.description: Identifies the name of specific module this data is coming from.

architecture.description: CPU architecture target for the file.

company.description: Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

compile_timestamp.description: Compile timestamp of the PE file.

creation_date.description: Extracted when possible from the file's metadata. Indicates when it was built or compiled. It can also be faked by malware creators.

debug.description: An array containing an object for each debug entry, if present. The expected fields for this nested object fall under the `debug.` prefix.

type.description: Information type generated by the debug options.

description.description: Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

entry_point.description: Relative byte offset to the base of the PE file.

exports.description: List of symbols exported by PE

file_version.description: Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

dhash.description: Difference Hash (dhash) to find files with a visually similar icon or thumbnail.

imphash.description: A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values. Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

machine_type.description: Machine type of the PE file.

original_file_name.description: Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

packers.description: List of packers and tools used.

product.description: Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

resources.description: An array containing an object for each PE resource, if present. The expected fields for this nested object fall under the `resources.` prefix.

entropy.description: Measurement of entropy randomness in the resources section.

filetype.description: File type of the resources section.

md5.description: MD5 hash of the header for the PE file.

sections.description: Data about sections of compiled binary PE

entropy.description: Measurement of entropy randomness in the file.

raw_size.description: Size of the section or the dize of the initialized data on disk.

virtual_address.description: Virtual address available to the file.

port.description: Identifies a threat indicator as a port number (irrespective of direction).

provider.description: Identifies the name of the intelligence provider.

bytes.description: Original bytes written with base64 encoding. For Windows registry operations, such as SetValueEx and RegQueryValueEx, this corresponds to the data pointed by `lp_data`. This is optional but provides better recoverability and should be populated for REG_BINARY encoded values.

strings.description: Content when writing string types. Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

type.description: Standard registry type for encoding contents

path.description: Full path, including hive, key and value

scanner_stats.description: Count of AV/EDR vendors that successfully detected malicious file or URL.

sightings.description: Number of times this indicator was observed conducting threat activity.

type.description: Type of indicator as represented by Cyber Observable in STIX 2.0. Expected values   * autonomous-system   * artifact   * directory   * domain-name   * email-addr   * file   * ipv4-addr   * ipv6-addr   * mac-addr   * mutex   * process   * software   * url   * user-account   * windows-registry-key   * x-509-certificate

id.description: The id of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software id.

name.description: The name of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software name.

platforms.description: The platform of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software platform. Expected values   * AWS   * Azure   * Azure AD   * GCP   * Linux   * macOS   * Network   * Office 365   * PRE   * SaaS   * Windows

reference.description: The reference URL of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software reference URL.

type.description: The type of software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®. While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software type. Expected values   * Malware   * Tool

id.description: The id of tactic used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® tactic, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002/ )

name.description: Name of the type of tactic used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® tactic, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002/)

reference.description: The reference url of tactic used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® tactic, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002/ )

id.description: The id of technique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® technique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/)

name.description: The name of technique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® technique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/)

reference.description: The reference url of technique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® technique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/)

id.description: The full id of subtechnique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® subtechnique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)

name.description: The name of subtechnique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® subtechnique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)

reference.description: The reference url of subtechnique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® subtechnique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)
